questions.prompt: A deterministic signal is characterized by:
options: Exact values from a mathematical formula
questions.correctAnswer: Exact values from a mathematical formula
questions.explanation: Deterministic signals have exact values that can be calculated from an explicit mathematical formula for any time t. If you know the formula, you know every value with probability 1.
Thermal noise is inherently randomâ€”caused by random electron motion, it has no formula and can only be described statistically. The others are all deterministic with explicit formulas.
SNR = Signal-to-Noise Ratio = Signal Power / Noise Power. It quantifies how much stronger the desired signal is compared to the unwanted noise. Higher SNR means cleaner signal.

questions.prompt: An SNR of 20 dB means the signal is ___ times stronger than noise.
questions.explanation: Converting from dB: SNR = 10^(dB/10) = 10^(20/10) = 10^2 = 100. A 20 dB SNR means the signal power is 100 times the noise power.
Speech is random because even the same person saying the same word produces slightly different waveforms each time. No formula can predict exact speech valuesâ€”we can only describe it statistically.

questions.prompt: For a deterministic signal, the probability of its calculated value equals:
questions.explanation: Deterministic signals have probability = 1 for their calculated values. If x(t) = cos(t), then x(0) = 1 with absolute certainty. No randomness, no probability distributionâ€”just certainty.
Random signals cannot be described by explicit formulasâ€”instead we characterize them by their probability density functions (PDFs), mean, variance, and other statistical measures.

questions.prompt: In y(t) = x(t) + n(t), what does n(t) represent?
questions.explanation: This is the fundamental communication model: y(t) = received signal, x(t) = transmitted message (deterministic), n(t) = noise (random). The receiver must estimate x from the corrupted y.
Deterministic analysis uses straightforward calculus and algebra, while random signals require probability theory and stochastic processes. We master the simpler case first, then add complexity.
